column12: complementary and robust. It is our intention to include the Minister for Health and the Minister for Education and Skills in the development of the action plan. I will commence all remaining provisions of the Children First Act 2015 on 11 December next. The ongoing role of the statutory Children First interdepartmental implementation group
column13: which is chaired by my Department

column15: the HSE
column16: the Garda and Tusla. Issues relating to Internet safety
column17: which have a child protection dimension and which require cross-Government collaboration or support
column18: can be raised in that group. The national youth health programme is a partnership between the HSE
column19: the National Youth Council of Ireland and my Department. It aims to provide a broad-based
column20: flexible health promotion-education support and training service to youth organisations and to all those working with young people in out-of-school settings. The Web Safety in Youth Work resource
column21: available on the National Youth Council of Ireland’s website
column22: provides valuable advice to young people on reporting online behaviour and passing on concerns about the protection and welfare of a child or young person.

column1: #AnneRabbitte	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-party	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-dob	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	236	I thank the Minister for her reply. column9: and Communications

column12: as we heard last week
column13: do not feel they have the tools to do their job? How can we move forward to educate?

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	237	I would be willing to accept that invitation and I am certain that my colleagues would also. As the Deputy identified

column1: #SeanSherlock	Labour	16428	Cork East	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	240	There are 124 school completion programmes throughout the State

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	241	I believe the school completion programme is critical to ensuring that children who are most at risk of early school leaving are supported to stay in education. However
column2: I believe that it needs to be reformed to ensure that it delivers the best possible outcomes for children. To this end
column3: I am examining carefully how best to strengthen it. Any reforms will be informed by the Economic and Social Research Institute
column4: ESRI
column5: review of the programme
column6: which acknowledged its great contribution to vulnerable children
column7: but which pointed to the need for an improved governance structure and revised model of employment. In particular
column8: I want to ensure that services under the programme are compliant with financial and governance rules and that we have a good model of service delivery throughout the country. I also want to ensure that those employed under the programme have clear contracts of employment and that their work is properly co-ordinated. I am deeply committed to an effective reform of this programme
column9: not only in relation to the governance and employment issues
column10: but also the programmes
column11: supports and processes that are in place to ensure that young people complete school. I am reviewing the extensive consultation process that has been carried out. I am considering recommendations from the expert panel that Tusla has established to consider possible options for reform. I also plan to consult with experts across the educational welfare sector before making any decisions. In my view the reform will incorporate universal supports as well as targeted supports to ensure that those most in need are reached by the programme. It is critical that we have a whole school approach to this
column12: as well as ensuring that other child and family supports
column13: delivered by statutory or voluntary agencies
column14: are integrated so that the child or young person has the best chance of staying in school. I am also committed to incorporating recognition of the strengths and capabilities of the child or young person into these reforms. I believe the emotional stability of the young person is critical in enabling his or her engagement in learning and contributes to his or her desire to finish school.

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	247	We have made good progress in implementing the access and inclusion model
column2: AIM
column3: which helps children with disabilities to reap the full benefits of free preschool education. Its goal is to empower preschool providers to deliver an inclusive preschool experience. As the Deputy is aware
column4: AIM is a child-centred model that involves seven levels of progressive support
column5: moving from the universal to the targeted. It is based on the needs of the child and the preschool setting. Since the introduction of AIM in June 2016
column6: it has enhanced free preschool education for all children
column7: particularly children with a disability. When a preschool provider
column8: in conjunction with a parent
column9: considers that additional support is needed for a child with a disability
column10: an application can be made via Pobal for a suite of targeted supports. These supports involve access to mentoring from a team of dedicated early years specialists at level four; access to specialised equipment
column11: appliances and minor alteration grants at level five; access to therapeutic services at level six; and access to additional capitation to facilitate lower adult to child ratios at level seven. An application for support at levels four
column12: six or seven is generally responded to by an early years specialist within two to three days. This is followed by an observation visit
column13: which generally takes place within two to four weeks
column14: depending on the availability of the preschool provider and the attendance pattern of the child. An application for support at level six is referred to the HSE within days of the observation visit. An application for support at level seven is generally appraised within two to five weeks. The application process for support at level five
column15: which involves equipment and alterations
column16: is separate. The appraisal process for such applications is usually completed within two weeks and equipment or appliances are delivered within four to 12 weeks
column17: depending on availability and supplier delivery terms for the items required. In the current preschool year
column18: more than 3
column19: 000 applications have been approved for targeted AIM supports. There has been one appeal on the decisions. This suggests that access to the model is good.

column6: frustratingly
column7: it takes 50 working days
column8: or ten weeks
column9: for the whole assessment to be put through. One of the first announcements made by the Minister and the Minister of State

column11: involved the provision of €40 million for the project. There are 1

column9: 443 children benefitted from level four supports and 1

column11: unfortunately

column13: which means that 1
column14: 272 fewer children are in the system this year. I wonder whether the timeframe is the reason for this.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	252	Deputy Rabbitte is working overtime.

column2: I ask the Minister to set out the steps she is taking to ensure such failings are addressed. I am asking this question on the back of last week's publication by HIQA of its second Cork report
column3: which is based on the findings of the first Cork report.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	254	I welcome HIQA's important work on foster care services and the report prepared by the Oireachtas joint committee. I will respond to the joint committee by the end of the year. In Ireland
column2: 92% of children living in care are in foster care placements
column3: which is an enviable situation. This compares favourably to foster care services overseas. The most recent figures for England show that 74% of children in care were in foster placements. The figure in Northern Ireland is 80% for children who have been in care for at least 12 months. The vast majority of foster placements are stable and loving long-term arrangements in which children are nurtured and supported. By the end of last year
column4: HIQA had inspected all foster care services. It findings show that
column5: in general
column6: children in foster care are safe
column7: happy and in good health and are attending school. For 2017
column8: HIQA has focused in more detail on specific standards
column9: such as the checks and balances that foster care committees and senior managers should have in place to support safe and effective services. Children's experience of the service was not assessed during 2017. This year's inspections show delays in completing formal assessments of relative carers and the lack of regular reviews of all foster carers. The need for Garda vetting for children over the age of 16 and young adults in the household has also been highlighted. There are weaknesses in how some foster care committees are informed about complaints and allegations against foster carers. I am pleased to note that HIQA has accepted Tusla’s action plans with regard to the inspection reports. I am monitoring the improvements that are being made.The clear themes coming through are the need for better oversight
column10: the recruitment of staff
column11: the replenishment and broadening of foster care panels
column12: improved supports and the supervision of foster carers. I am asking Tusla to provide me with a national strategy for the recruitment of foster carers as part of its 2018 business plan and to build on and improve the assessment of and support for foster carers. I have secured additional funding of over €40 million for Tusla to ensure the business plan can be achieved.

column1: #AnneRabbitte	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-party	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-dob	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	255	It is welcome to hear that the Minister is looking for a national strategy in the business plan for 2018 because when the report on the situation in Cork came out the other day
column2: it made for very worrying reading. It found that a number of key recommendations made in the previous report had still not been addressed
column3: least of all the recommendation on Garda vetting. It also found that a number of families who were fostering children in care had not been subjected to Garda vetting. That is a huge issue. We have to drill deep to find out why Garda vetting is still an issue
column4: despite being the most fundamental part of any of the reports presented
column5: including the Tusla and HIQA reports. In this day and age
column6: Garda vetting should not be an issue in cases where children are in care. We need to find out why this has repeatedly been an issue. I am concerned that a number of the four key recommendations made in the Cork report had still not been addressed. We have to find out why they were not addressed
column7: when they will be addressed and who is going to be held accountable. What role does the Minister's Department play in all of this? The fact is there is now a second report.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	256	HIQA sends its reports directly to me and my Department. To respond to the Deputy's last query and issue
column2: as she says
column3: there was an inspection of foster care services in Cork in February and a follow-up inspection at the end of August. The follow-up inspection took place before many of the actions recommended were due to be completed
column4: as shown in Tusla's action plan as accepted by HIQA. Therefore
column5: the findings were to be expected as many of the actions recommended were still under way. For example
column6: the rolling out of a new process to manage concerns and allegations involving foster carers had been recommended as an action
column7: but it could not be commented on in the report because no new reports had been received since the new policy came into effect in July. The inspection report indicates that progress is being made and in line with the expected progress shown in the action plan. HIQA noted that some actions had been completed
column8: but it was concerned that their completion was not timely or of good quality. I will seek to have Tusla confirm to me that the position has improved following the most recent inspection. On Garda vetting
column9: I accept that it is an issue
column10: although not across the board. As the Deputy is aware
column11: one of the things I have been doing in the context of the wider approach taken by Tusla is working with An Garda Síochána. We have been looking very closely at the issue and had several meetings to discuss the ways in which interagency co-operation can be improved.

column1: #AnneRabbitte	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-party	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-dob	unknown-#AnneRabbitte-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	257	As the Minister is aware
column2: the Joint Committee on Children and Youth Affairs carried out a scope of works in respect of foster care services. One of the recommendations made by the committee was that the powers afforded to HIQA be extended to include powers of enforcement. Earlier today representatives of HIQA were before the committee to discuss the Oberstown Children Detention Campus. While HIQA has a monitoring role
column3: it needs to have an implementation role. There is no point in producing reports unless it has good oversight
column4: implementation and enforcement powers. I would welcome the Minister's commentary in that regard.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	258	I am aware of the joint committee's recommendations. There are some details in the report
column2: including those relating to the cost of Tusla's provision of private foster care
column3: on which I hope to obtain more information before responding to the recommendations overall. I am happy to say some of that work with Tusla is in hand. It ties in with the recommendations of the committee. My officials will be writing to the CEO of Tusla to seek its formal response to the report which will be incorporated into my reply on the committee's recommendations which I hope to give as soon as possible. The Deputy raised the issue of expanding the role of HIQA to include enforcement and regulation. My Department wrote to HIQA following its presentation to the joint committee about the issues raised. As the Deputy is aware
column4: HIQA is largely involved with developing standards and inspecting services
column5: but it has indicated that it would like to be given a role in regulation. I am open to having that discussion with Tusla. I want to hear its views on how any proposed change could improve the lives of children in foster care. I am also open to having discussions with HIQA on future revisions to foster care standards.

column1: #JohnCurranFF	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-party	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-dob	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	259	Will the Minister fast-track a review of the service provision of family resource centres by Tusla to allow centres with only two members of staff an opportunity to secure additional funding and work from a base of three staff?

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	260	Family resource centres play a really important role in communities across the country. I am personally convinced by the work they do in identifying and providing the services most needed by their communities. It is for this reason that the Government has provided additional funding of almost €3 million for family resource centres in 2018. As part of this allocation
column2: I am pleased to confirm that additional funding of €10
column3: 000 will be made available to each family resource centre. Tusla will have discussions with centres about service needs
column4: funding and staffing resources. On the operation of family resource centres
column5: the Deputy will be aware that they are independent organisations which are managed by voluntary boards of management which represent the local community. The centres operate independently of Tusla. Each centre is responsible for the recruitment of employees and the terms and conditions under which they are employed. The Deputy may also be aware that last week Tusla announced once-off funding for small capital works of €2.12 million for the 109 existing family resource centres.  I am placing strong emphasis on the development of capacity within the family resource centre programme next year. Tusla
column6: the Child and Family Agency
column7: allocates funding to 109 family resource centres. I have provided funding for Tusla to increase this number by 11
column8: bringing to 120 the number of family resource rentres that will be operational next year. Family resource centres are critical to prevention and early intervention. Through their services and engagement
column9: they can spot potential difficulties for children and families before they emerge as serious issues. They support families and in so doing make an invaluable contribution to keeping children safe and well.

column1: #JohnCurranFF	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-party	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-dob	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	261	I acknowledge the additional funding which the Minister has indicated will be made available next year. The question I am asking is slightly different in that historically we have had 109 family resource centres
column2: approximately 45 of which work from a base of three core staff
column3: while the remainder work with two. The problem is that the additional funding will not be sufficient to allow some of these family resource centres which operate in disadvantaged areas an opportunity to grow. Having met representatives of some of the family resource centres
column4: while one-off grants are always welcome
column5: it is very hard for centres to plan from one year to the next without a sustainable level of core funding. The challenge I am meeting is that a substantial number of centres which have only two core staff and which are operating in areas experiencing significant disadvantage cannot seem to obtain the additional funding required from Tusla to transition from a base of two staff to three. That is the challenge we are facing.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	262	I am very pleased to engage with the Deputy on this issue. I understand and I am aware of the concerns about some family resource centres throughout the country. I have an absolute commitment to and an understanding of the incredible work done by family resource centres. Therefore
column2: I was determined to ensure we would be able to invest more next year
column3: as well as making more support available this year. As I have identified
column4: we have recently done that. This commitment is demonstrated in providing more money for the centres
column5: and for expanding their number throughout the country. As the Deputy can appreciate
column6: I have also received many representations in that regard. I see this as the first step towards increasing the level of investment in family resource centres. I accept some of the points raised by the Deputy
column7: but this is a significant first step and a demonstration of our commitment.

column1: #JohnCurranFF	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-party	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-dob	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	263	I thank the Minister. When she has time we may be able to visit Quarryvale family resource centre. Its grant for 2017 was €86
column2: 500. When the Minister was announcing additional funding on Friday last
column3: she spoke about 11 new family resource centres and made available funding of €1.76 million for them
column4: which is €160
column5: 000 per family resource centre and almost double what the Quarryvale family resource centre currently receives. The centre is very constrained. Too much of the time of development workers there is taken up with fundraising to keep essential services running. In an area of huge disadvantage
column6: those workers now hear of new family resource centres that will be funded at twice the level of their centre. Therein lies the challenge. I acknowledge that the Minister is expanding the number of centres but some family resource centres that are working from the core base of two employees have huge issues in their areas. They do not just need an annual grant
column7: their core funding must be significantly increased to allow them move from a two-person to three-person operations in order to meet the needs in their communities.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	264	As regards Quarryvale family resource centre and as the Deputy is aware
column2: the funding of €86
column3: 478 covers the salaries of a full-time co-ordinator
column4: a part-time development worker and a part-time administrator. When Quarryvale entered the programme in 2005
column5: its original budget was set at €39
column6: 777. Whether the same criteria are used to determine the annual funding of family resource centres depends on when the project entered the programme. The number of staff
column7: location
column8: size and catchment area of the centre and the deprivation index of the area are also taken into account. Quarryvale is in the lower funding bracket due to its only having two staff - as the Deputy identified - as well as the date on which it entered the programme. It is located in an area of high deprivation. The Deputy has raised these issues and I have asked that they be examined. I am investing money in the sector. I understand the concerns raised by the Deputy and I will ask Tusla to note them
column9: particularly in the context of Quarryvale
column10: for the future.

column1: #DeniseMitchell	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-party	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-dob	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	265	When will the Minister publish the national early years strategy and when will it be implemented?

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	266	Better Outcomes
column2: Brighter Futures
column3: the national policy framework for children and young people
column4: contains a commitment to publish Ireland's first-ever national early years strategy. The ten-year cross-Government strategy will focus on the period of early childhood from birth to five and cover all aspects of children's lives. Given the importance of the first five years for childhood development and for development over the life course
column5: the strategy is a priority for me. No other strategy offers the same potential to transform the lives of children and their families. It is
column6: therefore
column7: important that we get it right. Drafting of the strategy is being advanced by my Department
column8: which is drawing on substantial national and international research evidence and being informed by experts' views
column9: including those of the expert advisory group on the early years strategy
column10: bilateral meetings with other Departments and a range of stakeholder consultations
column11: including one undertaken with children aged three to five. We also held a very valuable open policy debate which brought together over 80 experts from the fields of health
column12: education
column13: early childhood care and education
column14: child protection
column15: housing
column16: community
column17: social protection and social inclusion. A draft strategy has been prepared and a process of redrafting is about to commence alongside further consultation with Departments and key stakeholders. Efforts to progress the remaining work and finalise the strategy for publication have recently intensified with the assignment of an additional resource by my Department. When it is published as early as possible in 2018
column18: my Department will outline a plan for implementation that will involve the close monitoring of progress on all actions within the agreed timeframes.

column1: #DeniseMitchell	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-party	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-dob	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	267	The national early years strategy presents us with a very important opportunity to identify what is in the best interests of every child from birth to six years of age. It includes a specific focus on early childhood care and education. I acknowledge the work that has been carried out by the Minister such as brainstorming sessions and policy debates with stakeholders to progress the strategy. However
column2: while there have been various schemes and announcements regarding early years services
column3: I fear that
column4: although it is well-meaning
column5: the strategy is disjointed. I would like it to be published as soon as possible. The Minister said that will be done in 2018 but this process has been ongoing for a long period and I hope she will be able to give a date for its publication and implementation.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	268	I thank the Deputy. The first area she identified relates to whether we are being strategic. We do not yet have a strategy. As regards why it has been delayed
column2: the commitment to publish the strategy coincided with a commitment to totally reform the early childhood care and education sector in Ireland. As the Deputy is aware
column3: my Department has been engaged in many initiatives and a significant reform agenda at the same time as trying to progress the strategy. Examples of its work are the report on the future investment in child care
column4: the early years regulations
column5: the access and inclusion model
column6: the action plan for school age child care
column7: the expansion of the ECCE
column8: early childhood care and education
column9: scheme and more affordable child care measures in 2017. While I acknowledge there has been a delay
column10: it has been contributed to by that significant reform.

column1: #DeniseMitchell	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-party	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-dob	unknown-#DeniseMitchell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	269	The strategy
column2: when published
column3: needs to include an implementation plan. Over the years
column4: we have all seen various well-meaning schemes whose clear goals have sometimes fallen flat. What plans does the Minister have to fund and prioritise the strategy?

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	270	I assure the Deputy that an implementation plan will be part of the strategy. We will draw on the learning we have gained from the experience and cross-Departmental work that has been carried out
column2: in particular in the context of the Better Outcomes
column3: Brighter Futures national ten-year strategy whereby high-level officials gather every quarter under my chairmanship and have worked together to understand and ensure that implementation will be the focus once the report has been published. That will enable us to have the strategy and also a structure for its implementation. As part of that process there will
column4: in the first instance
column5: be an identification of the aspects of budgets within Departments that are already focused on ensuring that parts of the plan are resourced
column6: as well as working together to be able to identify resource gaps that will have to be filled to ensure the plan is implemented.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	271	I want to ask the Minister about funding for youth work at Laois youth work centre. The county has consistently received a very small slice of the cake in that regard. For example
column2: in the current year it received €107
column3: 000 while Cavan received €333
column4: 000 - although I am not arguing for the Minister to take money off Cavan - and Wexford received €440

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	272	Funding to staff-led youth services has generally been targeted at areas of disadvantage and not allocated in proportion to the youth population of a county. That has had an impact on Laois's funding relative to other counties. Laois youth services received €86
column2: 803 in funding in 2017 under the special projects for youth scheme. Under the scheme
column3: grant aid is made available in respect of out-of-school projects for disadvantaged young people. Priority is given to projects in the spheres of special youth work initiatives
column4: young homeless people
column5: young people at risk of substance abuse and young Travellers. In addition
column6: funding has been provided to Laois and Offaly Education and Training Board under the local youth club grant scheme
column7: youth capital funding scheme and the local youth club equipment scheme. My Department also funds 31 national and major regional voluntary youth organisations. Foróige is funded through the scheme and provides a service to support 11 youth clubs in County Laois . Other clubs operating in County Laois that are affiliated to national organisations that receive funding from my Department include Macra na Feirme
column8: Youth Work Ireland
column9: the Irish Girl Guides
column10: ECO-Unesco
column11: the Order of Malta and Scouting Ireland.In 2017 I allocated €57.4 million in current funding to support the provision of youth services. This was an increase of €5.5 million on the allocation for 2016. I have enhanced it by a further €1.5 million in 2018. I am committed to continuing to seek additional investment in youth services. The Deputy will be aware that my Department is managing the most significant reform of youth services ever undertaken. Earlier this year I approved funding of €800
column12: 000 for the establishment of new youth projects and the augmentation of a small number of existing youth services to meet new challenges arising from population increases. Future development of and investment in youth services will be informed by the recently completed exercise which mapped youth service provision across the State.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	273	I thank the Minister for her reply. It is welcome that we have a Minister for Children and Youth Affairs. It is one of the more positive things that have happened in recent years. The Minister has mentioned that funding is allocated not necessarily in proportion to the size of the youth population but rather based on income and disadvantage. With respect
column2: I point out to her in comparison to the other 25 counties County Laois has a low income figure per head of population. For a rural county we also have a huge concentration of foreign nationals. There are many children whose home language is not English or Irish and this creates a lot of difficulties. There is a high unemployment rate because the collapse of the construction industry hit County Laois severely. Very many people travel to work in Dublin in construction. There is a significant level of disadvantage in County Laois. Out of a population of 86
column5: 500 people commute every day. Of the €57.4 million in current funding the Department of Children and Youth Affairs has allocated to support the provision of youth services
column6: County Laois received just €86
column7: 000 which represents 0.15% of the total sum. According to the census
column8: the youth population in the county is growing rapidly. Some 24.6% of the people living in the county are under 14 years of age and there has been a 26.3% increase in the youth population in the past ten years.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	274	We need to hear from the Minister or we will not fit in everyone's questions.

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	275	I am aware
column2: not just from the Deputy's question but also from my work
column3: of the significant level of disadvantage in County Laois. As the Deputy says
column4: there has been a certain amount of investment
column5: particularly in the special projects for youth scheme. I have talked about other investment in County Laois
column6: but we are focusing
column7: in particular
column8: on the special projects for youth scheme. The mapping exercise carried out by Pobal which shows how the social demographics have changed in a given area potentially offers an opportunity for more investment. I think some officials in County Laois are in conversation and having meetings with my Department
column9: looking at how to support the best approach to accessing and making applications for grants and there is willingness to continue to support the officers concerned to ensure their grant applications will ultimately be successful.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	276	Some of the electoral divisions in County Laois
column2: including places such as Mountrath and Mountmellick and parts of Portlaoise and other towns

column5: but
column6: as the Minister mentioned
column7: County Laois was also unsuccessful in that regard. I am trying to point out to her that the local youth services
column8: specifically Youth Work Laois
column9: do tremendous work but that an awful lot of their time is spent in trying to access funding. I have been in and out of this issue
column10: as have other public representatives. There is a huge stretch on the resources available to these services which are under huge pressure. I ask the Minister and her officials to look again at this issue. Towards the end of the year public bodies

column12: sometimes have a little money left in the kitty. The Minister will start off next year with a new budget. I ask her to look at County Laois
column13: in particular
column14: to ensure there is a fair divvying up.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	277	Does the Minister have any money left in the kitty for County Laois?

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	278	Exactly.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	279	I ask her not to forget south Kildare also.

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	280	I will check. I understand the points made by the Deputy.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	281	I make them to the Minister genuinely.

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	282	There has been a new mapping exercise and a profiling that gives us additional information

It is my understanding that later this week my Department
column3: with the Centre for Effective Services

column6: on that basis

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	283	I take the opportunity to ask about the plans to review the allowances and funding paid to foster parents who carry out a very important role
column2: given the increased funding of €40 million for Tusla in budget 2018. I am sure the Minister will agree that foster carers are a vital resource in the care system
column3: in looking after almost 92% of the total number of children in care. At the end of July there were 5
column4: 801 children in foster care. I point to the extra resources needed to further support foster parents and the fact that we need to attract new foster parents.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	284	I have no plans to change the rate of the foster care allowance at this time. However
column2: my Department has begun an extensive review of the Child Care Act 1991 and will examine foster care arrangements as part of this review. It will have regard to income support measures available to foster families generally. I acknowledge foster carers as the backbone of child care services. Foster care is the preferred option in Ireland for children who cannot live with their parents or guardians. Approximately 92% of children in care are looked after by foster carers. More than one quarter of these children are placed with relative foster carers. The foster care allowance is currently €325 per week per child under 12 years of age and €352 per week per child aged 12 years and over. This payment was protected during recent economic hardships and is tax-free. It is paid in respect of the child and provided in order to allow foster carers to meet all of the child's daily living needs
column3: including food
column4: clothing
column5: basic travel
column6: education costs and hobbies and sports activities. The allowance is not considered as means for social welfare purposes. Foster carers also receive a number of targeted supports to ensure they continue to function as a recognised and valued part of the alternative care system. Key elements of this support include a link social worker
column7: access to training and support group meetings and the allocation of a social worker for each child in care. It is important that foster carers have access to specialist services to meet the child's identified needs. Respite care for children may be arranged if it is part of their care plan. Pre-assessment and ongoing training are compulsory for foster carers in order to equip them with the skills and knowledge to provide high quality care. Recognising the specific dynamics and the personal nature of relative care
column8: Tusla addresses the training needs of relatives who are foster carers separately. In addition
column9: Tusla provides funding for the Irish Foster Care Association which offers a range of supports to carers
column10: including advocacy
column11: mediation
column12: training and a telephone advice service.

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	285	I thank the Minister for her response. We need to review how foster parents are rewarded and recompensed for the work she has outlined
column2: work which
column3: we must acknowledge
column4: saves the State an awful lot of money. When were the allowances last reviewed? From talking to foster parents who have been fostering for many years and do not remember a change in the rates
column5: my sense is that they have not been reviewed for a very long time. The Minister has outlined foster carers' responsibilities and what the money is for: clothes
column6: food
column7: accommodation
column8: classes and education. She has said it does not act as a payment in any way for foster parents. However
column9: we need to recognise that the obligations placed on foster parents have increased
column10: rightly so. Under Children First
column11: they are now being asked to take on additional reporting obligations. There are extra responsibilities and they are taking on the role of a social worker. Will the Minister comment on an anomaly that arises in regard to the rates of allowance for which foster carers are eligible? As she indicated
column12: the rate is €325 per week for children aged under 12 and €352 for the over 12s. However
column13: once a child reaches 18 years of age
column14: the rate drops to €300. Given the high uptake of transition year
column15: many students are not finishing second level by the time they turn 18. Moreover
column16: it is probably much more expensive to care for an 18 year old than a 14 year old
column17: but families are getting €52 less per week for an older child.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	286	I do not know when the rates were last reviewed but I will find that out for the Deputy.

#MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	287	I understand it was not done recently.

#KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	288	If it is the case
column2: as he suggests
column3: that the rates have not been reviewed recently
column4: it is even more important that this should be done in the context of the extensive review of the Child Care Act in which my Department is engaged. The points the Deputy has raised are timely and all of them circle around the extraordinary contribution foster carers make to the protection and care of children and to Irish society in general. All of these issues will be considered as part of the wider consultation associated with the review of the Child Care Act. I expect that consultation to include an examination of the rationale for an increase in allowance rates in the context of the increased costs facing foster carers and the additional supports they may require.

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	289	The concerns I am raising are compounded by the difficulties being experienced by foster parents in qualifying for the contributory pension. The problem here is that what they do is not seen as work. I understand this particular issue is outside the Minister's remit and may be more properly a matter for the Department of Social Protection. However
column2: as Minister with ultimate responsibility for foster parents
column3: I look forward to teasing out the matter with her in the future with a view to championing the cause of foster parents in this regard. While foster carers qualify for homemaker's credits until their foster children are 12
column4: thereafter they are deemed to be not working and are being told they must get a part-time job. They are expected to do so while also caring for teenagers who are often very vulnerable. We must ensure the role of foster parent is recognised as a job that qualifies for credits and thereby allows them to qualify for a contributory pension. Some 92% of the children in the care of the State
column5: many of them requiring a great deal of support
column6: are looked after on our behalf by foster carers. Those carers are deserving of adequate practical support
column7: such as the retention of the higher-rate allowance and the mileage payment of 33 cent per mile after their foster child turns 18. In addition to this practical provision
column8: there also must be an acknowledgment on the part of the State of the very important role foster parents perform and a clear statement of the desirability of ensuring they are adequately supported. That is vital if we are to continue to attract people into this vital role in the future.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	290	The Deputy has made his points very well. As I said
column2: they are timely in the context of the review being conducted within my Department. The Deputy referred in particular to the income supports that are provided to those who take on this important and special role on behalf of the State. As I set out in my reply
column3: there are other forms of support in addition to income support that are part of the system and are also significant. These include regular home visits and telephone contact from an assigned fostering link worker and the allocation of a social worker to each child
column4: who visits the child and maintains a link with his or her birth family. In addition
column5: foster carers may apply for child benefit for each child in their care and there is a comprehensive training programme for carers at both the pre-approval and post-approval stage. Each child in foster care will have his or her own medical card. These additional supports illustrate the effort on the part of the State to acknowledge the extraordinary role carried out by foster carers.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	293	I propose to take Questions Nos. 45 and 60 together. An allocation of €6.86 million was secured in budget 2018 for my Department's capital funding programme. As in 2017
column2: this will be allocated to early years and school age child care capital projects. An official announcement on the specification of the capital programme for 2018 is due to be made in the coming week and will see the early years and school age capital programmes running concurrently. There also will be a continuation of the childminding development grant
column3: CMDG. Officials in my Department have listened to feedback from providers in developing the capital programme 2018. The result of this will be a programme that builds on previous successes while also ensuring an earlier
column4: more efficient delivery than in 2017. Delivery this year was delayed by two factors
column5: namely
column6: the huge volume of applications from providers seeking to improve or expand their services and
column7: second
column8: the possibility of incorporating significant extra funding into the capital programme from savings made elsewhere in the Department. We have learned from the difficulties experienced by providers as a result of this delay.  Departmental officials have liaised with Pobal and with city and county child care committees
column9: CCCs
column10: in order to determine the focus
column11: priorities and structure of the capital programme
column12: with a specific view to opening applications early in 2018. This will allow for significantly earlier appraisal and notification processes than in previous years. It will also provide for sign-off on the commencement of capital works approved for funding early in the summer of 2018. This represents a significant improvement on the timeline achieved under this year's programme and will be of significant benefit to providers working hard to deliver quality affordable child care in Ireland.  As in previous years
column13: I anticipate great demand for capital grant funding in 2018. The programme will assist in achieving providers' goals in terms of the improvement
column14: maintenance and expansion of child care services
column15: with a particular focus on where this is most needed. Following the announcement of the specifications of the programme in the coming days
column16: child care providers should be encouraged to make contact with their local CCC to obtain guidance on capital applications and any other issues relating to their service.

column1: #JohnCurranFF	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-party	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-dob	unknown-#JohnCurranFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	294	The Minister indicated that next year's capital programme will be announced earlier in the year than was the case in 2017. The capital programme for this year was announced in July
column2: at which point
column3: the Minister indicated
column4: there was an immediate draw-down of funds. This allocation covered hundreds of projects with the objective of creating 2
column5: 200 new child care places. Given that the funding was not announced until July
column6: will the Minister indicate
column7: as we approach year's end
column8: whether all the funds have been drawn down and all the additional places created? How much earlier in the year can the 2018 programme be delivered? Will the Minister indicate the global figure for capital projects in 2018? The allocation for 2017 was €8.4 million
column9: which is virtually double the sum for the previous year. It is important to ensure projects are identified and funding earmarked earlier in the year so that the full allocation can be drawn down in that year.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	295	The total capital budget allocation for 2016 and 2017 was increased during each programme's run
column2: in response to the extraordinary levels of demand from providers. Those increases were achieved through moving funds that arose out of savings and underspends elsewhere in my Department. For 2017
column3: the total allocation ended up being €12.4 million. While the current capital allocation for 2018 of €6.86 million is not as high as the final figure for this year
column4: it represents a significant increase on 2017's original baseline allocation of €5 million. On the question of when funding is announced
column5: I have tried to learn from the past and am absolutely determined to ensure applications are received as soon as possible so that plans can be made
column6: moneys spent and improvements achieved. On the amounts drawn down in 2017
column7: I will get that information for the Deputy.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	299	As the Minister is aware
column2: there are now more than 3
column3: 200 children living in hotel rooms
column4: family hubs
column5: bed and breakfast accommodation
column6: domestic violence refuges and other unsuitable and cramped accommodation. The Minister and her Government committed to ending the use of hotel rooms and that type of accommodation for accommodating families who are homeless by 1 July 2017. That deadline was missed. Although some families were moved into hubs
column7: I believe 690 families are still in hotel rooms. Has the Minister carried out any studies in respect of the physical and mental health impacts of this on children? Is there any follow-up when
column8: hopefully and at long last
column9: they receive permanent accommodation? What weekly actions will the Minister take in order to protect and care for the welfare of those children? For example
column10: has the Minister visited any of the hotels or hubs in question?

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	300	I propose to take Questions Nos. 47 and 51 together. I thank Deputy Broughan for the excellent questions. I believe the Deputy is aware that I am committed to helping children and families as part of the whole-of-Government response to the problem of homelessness. I believe that living in emergency accommodation such as hotels and bed and breakfast accommodation impacts negatively on the health of children and their families. Living in very confined spaces gives rise to a lot of stress. Children have no facilities to do their homework. Parents have spoken to me about the difficulty in toilet training toddlers. My Department has co-funded a study on food access and nutritional health among families living in hotel accommodation. It did not make for pleasant reading but it absolutely confirmed that this type of accommodation is not conducive to healthy children or healthy families. We are trying to find a solution which
column2: in the medium term
column3: provides an environment where children and families can live in a less stressed
column4: less cramped environment. This is why the Minister for Housing
column5: Planning and Local Government has accelerated the provision of family hubs. I have visited some of these myself
column6: both purpose built and an existing building. Importantly
column7: they provide space for children to play. The hubs also provide a better setting for supports such as homework clubs
column8: meeting with support workers and activities that are organised for both children and parents. They are not a long-term solution but
column9: in my opinion and from what families have told me
column10: the hubs are a big improvement on hotels and bed and breakfast accommodation. There are currently 11 hubs in operation. Ten of these are in Dublin and one is in Limerick. Between them
column11: they provide just over 300 units of family accommodation. Four new hubs will be delivered before the end of the year. These will provide more than 100 additional units of family accommodation in Dublin. Two further new hubs will be delivered in Limerick before the end of the year
column12: providing 34 units of family accommodation. Early next year
column13: there will be more than 55 further units of family accommodation in Dublin with the opening of two new hubs. In addition
column14: there will be a 19 unit family hub opening in Cork early in the new year. There is a proposal in planning for a hub in Galway. Through my Department
column15: I have introduced free child care for the children of families experiencing homelessness. Some families are already eligible under existing schemes. I am happy to say that the families of an additional 154 children are availing of this measure
column16: which also provides for a daily meal for the child. This was introduced as a direct response to a request from the homeless agencies to do this. It was a response to the needs of the child and also the needs of the parents. In addition
column17: I asked Tusla to fund the provision of child support workers for one of the homeless agencies
column18: which it has done. It has also appointed a homelessness liaison officer who works with all the other agencies and providers helping homeless families. As we discussed earlier
column19: Tusla also has responsibility for the school completion programme. This provides supports for children at risk of not reaching their potential in the educational system. It does this through initiatives such as after-school supports
column20: homework clubs
column21: mentoring programmes
column22: therapeutic interventions
column23: and breakfast clubs. In response to the homeless crisis
column24: all school completion programmes now engage with schools on an ongoing basis
column25: not just at the start of the year
column26: so that children who become homeless during the course of the year are provided with support through the school completion programme. Tusla and the Dublin Region Homeless Executive
column28: are also supporting an initiative to support women who are pregnant and homeless or at risk of homelessness. Tusla is providing funding for the recruitment of support workers for this service. Our children and their families need permanent homes. That is the goal of the Government. In the meantime
column29: I will continue to support measures to help these children and their families
column30: both within my area of responsibility and also with colleagues in other Departments.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	301	I thank the Minister for her reply. The Minister referred to a study on food access and nutrition. Will this report be published or will it be made available to Deputies? Earlier today
column2: Members spoke about the accountability of Ministers and the accountability of this House. After the past three or four years of watching families who are homeless ending up in hotel rooms and in hubs
column3: it seems to me that Ministers will be held accountable on this in future Dáileanna and maybe future tribunals. It is something to which the Minister needs to give daily attention. In my experience and from the reports I receive
column4: families have warned us of longer-term physical and mental health impacts on children of living in accommodation without cooking facilities
column5: without space for babies to crawl or learn to walk
column6: with missed visits from public health nurses and so on. These heartbreaking stories bring home to us how inappropriate these locations are
column7: especially the hotel room situation. Deputies get calls from desperate couples and mothers
column8: who realise that their children are really suffering day in and day out because of these conditions. With regard to family hubs
column9: I am aware that the Minister has probably looked at the excellent study by Dr. Rory Hearne and Dr. Mary Murphy on the operation of family hubs for the housing of families who are homeless. The clear indication of the report is that three months is the very maximum period a family should be in a hub. It is a desperate situation for those families who are suffering.

column1: #BernardJDurkan	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-party	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-dob	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	302	I thank the Deputy.

#TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	303	I represent people who have been in this situation for two years plus. We need a very strong response from the Department of Children and Youth Affairs and from the Department of Housing
column2: Planning and Local Government.

column1: #KatherineZappone	unknown-#KatherineZappone-party	unknown-#KatherineZappone-dob	unknown-#KatherineZappone-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	304	The Deputy is absolutely correct that the Ministers should be
column2: and are
column3: held accountable. I appreciate the Deputy's questions. He has raised some of them with me previously. On the question of researching and studying the mental health and well-being of the children
column4: I agree with the issues identified by Deputy Broughan. It is not good for the mental health and well-being of young children to be in bed and breakfast accommodation and emergency accommodation. I have seen this myself also when I have gone around. My initial
column5: and continued
column6: response in the context of my Department was to find ways to mitigate the impact of the difficulties that children and young people experience in that regard. Early on
column7: I identified some of those issues
column8: having consulted with the agencies about what would help in that context. The Deputy is absolutely right that we did not meet the deadline that was originally set. As part of the process towards meeting the deadline
column9: there was the establishment of family hubs. I have been in a couple of them and I have heard from the people who are there and say to me that the hubs are providing a very different way of ensuring supports for families ultimately to find secure accommodation and a housing solution for them. It is not just about the place. When I visited the Tallaght family hub
column10: I was told that families no longer had the responsibility of the self-accommodation option as they were self-accommodating with supports to help them find their housing solutions.

What is the reason service providers are not linking into the homeless PASS management system

column8: Planning and Local Government in relation to this? Does the Minister's Department and Tusla have an input into the Department of Housing

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	308	I propose

column1: #BernardJDurkan	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-party	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-dob	unknown-#BernardJDurkan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	309	Is that agreed? Agreed.

#RobertTroy	unknown-#RobertTroy-party	unknown-#RobertTroy-dob	unknown-#RobertTroy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	310	My purpose is to try to ascertain from the Minister of State with responsibility for sport exactly when the sports capital programme will be announced. Applications for the programme opened in January 2017 with a closing date of 24 February. That is over ten months ago. Many small
column2: voluntary sporting clubs in my constituency of Longford-Westmeath and right across the country put a lot of time
column3: effort and hard work into preparing their applications for the sports capital programme but to date there are some which do not know whether they will receive funding. I ask the Minister to give a clear undertaking as to when the official word will become known. I am also concerned that a number of colleagues have approached me over the last 24 to 48 hours to indicate that certain members of Government parties were ringing around sporting clubs to advise them that they had been successful and to expect a phone call later this week. If that is happening
column4: I am very worried. Funding allocations should be made known in an open and transparent manner to all Members of the Oireachtas. I am aware that there were a large number of applications this year. As such
column5: I welcome the fact that additional funding is being made available for the scheme. It is important
column6: however
column7: that the Minister of State sets out when he will announce the grants and states how many applications were deemed ineligible. Have applicants whose applications were ineligible already been made aware of that fact? If not
column8: why not? One imagines they should have been afforded the opportunity to submit whatever documentation was missing from their original applications. Finally
column9: can the Minister provide the House with the reason it has taken so long to go through the applications? The committees of local
column10: voluntary organisations
column11: which are made up of people working in a voluntary capacity
column12: must put forward applications in the space of seven weeks while a fully fledged and funded Department has yet to respond ten months later. These clubs are fundraising to ensure they meet the criteria and they have worked hard to ensure they can make the necessary improvements to their sporting facilities. I would welcome a response from the Minister of State.

column1: #BrendanGriffinFG	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-party	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-dob	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-11-28 00:00:00	Termination of Ministerial Appointment: Announcement by Taoiseach	311	I thank Deputy Troy. I agree completely that the sports capital programme is a very positive addition to Irish society. Since 1998
column2: €911 million has been spent on vital sporting facilities in large and small communities. The footprint is very visible in the communities where that €911 million has been spent. It has made a huge difference to sporting organisations
column3: many of which would be otherwise unable to raise funding for necessary infrastructure. I was delighted when the scheme was reintroduced in 2012
column4: having been scrapped in 2008 when the economic crisis hit. We were also able to introduce a scheme in 2014-15 and we have been able to do so again in 2017. When I came into the Department on 20 June
column5: applications had closed. At that stage
column6: there was a budget of €30 million for both the local and regional schemes
column7: with a breakdown of €26 million to €4 million
column8: respectively. Unfortunately
column9: the overall value of the 2
column10: 320 applications submitted for both the local and regional schemes was €155 million. Given those figures
column11: it would have been very difficult to reward in a meaningful way all of the volunteers to whom Deputy Troy referred had we attempted to spread the available funds across all of the applications. The first thing I did
column12: therefore
column13: was to consult with the Minister
column14: Deputy Shane Ross. We dug in and worked very hard in the months before the budget to increase the funding for the programme. We had a very successful outcome in the budget and managed to raise the available funding for the 2017 programme from €30 million to €60 million
column15: which was a considerable increase. It is to be hoped that level of funding will allow us to deliver a positive and progressive scheme on Thursday of this week. It will be very responsive to the needs of clubs around the country and help to clear a backlog which has built up. As Deputy Troy knows
column16: the breakdown in 2012 was that 48% of clubs made invalid applications. In 2014-15
column17: approximately one third were invalid. Due to changes which have been made to the scheme and the website
column18: we are looking at an invalid rate of approximately 20%
column19: which is a step in the right direction

column20: PwC

column2: which I am taking on behalf of the Minister for Communications
column3: Climate Action and Environment. I recognise the important part that public service broadcasters play in our democratic society. The provision of stable and adequate funding is essential to ensuring the continued delivery of their role in this regard. I am very much aware

column9: the rapid changes in technology altering the traditional way in which television is watched together with economic pressures generally means that a serious question mark exists over the ability of the current funding model to provide continued stable funding for public service media in the long term.  In October 2016
